pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 221]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 186, 905, 240]]<|/det|>
0625/12 February/March 2018 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 588, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 312, 386, 327]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 890, 415]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 890, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 489, 555, 504]]<|/det|>
## Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 578]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet. Electronic calculators may be used. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 775, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is asked to find the volume of a small irregularly-shaped piece of rock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 457, 120]]<|/det|>
He has the following apparatus available.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 131, 902, 357]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 369, 808, 386]]<|/det|>
Which apparatus must the student use to find the volume of the small piece of rock?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 294, 415]]<|/det|>
A balance and rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 426, 228, 441]]<|/det|>
B rule only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 418, 467]]<|/det|>
C balance and measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 478, 351, 493]]<|/det|>
D measuring cylinder only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 521, 96, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 520, 853, 537]]<|/det|>
The speed-time graph represents the motion of a car travelling along a straight level road.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 548, 667, 680]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 695, 527, 711]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the motion of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 723, 126, 742]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 723, 525, 740]]<|/det|>
It accelerates and reaches a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 750, 463, 766]]<|/det|>
B It accelerates and then stops moving.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 777, 567, 793]]<|/det|>
C It decelerates and then reaches a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 803, 463, 819]]<|/det|>
D It decelerates and then stops moving.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 656, 90]]<|/det|>
An athlete runs 300 metres up a hill at a steady speed of \(3.0 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 848, 120]]<|/det|>
She then immediately runs the same distance down the hill at a steady speed of \(6.0 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 530, 150]]<|/det|>
What is her average speed for the 600 metre run?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 720, 178]]<|/det|>
A \(2.0 \text{m/s}\) B \(3.0 \text{m/s}\) C \(4.0 \text{m/s}\) D \(4.5 \text{m/s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 206, 94, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 349, 223]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 235, 695, 252]]<|/det|>
A Mass is a gravitational force but weight is not a gravitational force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 261, 730, 278]]<|/det|>
B Mass is not a gravitational force and weight is not a gravitational force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 287, 717, 304]]<|/det|>
C The unit of mass is the kilogram and the unit of weight is the newton.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 717, 330]]<|/det|>
D The unit of mass is the newton and the unit of weight is the kilogram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 357, 94, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 357, 834, 374]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a bird in flight. The bird is flying in a horizontal direction to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 387, 555, 404]]<|/det|>
In which direction does air resistance act on the bird?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[302, 415, 692, 648]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 515, 90]]<|/det|>
A measuring cylinder contains \(30 \text{cm}^3\) of a liquid.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 102, 628, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 355, 764, 373]]<|/det|>
Some more of the liquid is added until the liquid level reaches the \(50 \text{cm}^3\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 497, 403]]<|/det|>
The reading on the balance increases by \(30 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 416, 388, 433]]<|/det|>
What is the density of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 737, 462]]<|/det|>
A \(0.60 \text{g} / \text{cm}^3\) B \(0.67 \text{g} / \text{cm}^3\) C \(1.5 \text{g} / \text{cm}^3\) D \(1.7 \text{g} / \text{cm}^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 490, 96, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 489, 794, 507]]<|/det|>
A car is travelling along a straight horizontal road. The speed-time graph is shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 520, 722, 537]]<|/det|>
In which labelled part of the journey is the resultant force on the car zero?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 547, 747, 702]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 732, 96, 750]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 732, 662, 750]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a uniform metre rule balanced at its mid-point.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 759, 750, 844]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 859, 515, 876]]<|/det|>
What is the weight \(W\) placed at the \(20 \text{cm}\) mark?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 887, 693, 905]]<|/det|>
A \(0.25 \text{N}\) B \(4.0 \text{N}\) C \(9.0 \text{N}\) D \(21 \text{N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 833, 90]]<|/det|>
A wooden plank rests in equilibrium on two rocks on opposite sides of a narrow stream.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 103, 460, 120]]<|/det|>
Three forces \(P,\) \(Q\) and \(R\) act on the plank.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 129, 785, 294]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 306, 445, 322]]<|/det|>
How are the sizes of the forces related?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 240, 425]]<|/det|>
A \(P + Q = R\) B \(P + R = Q\) C \(P = Q = R\) D \(P = Q + R\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 454, 107, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 456, 919, 489]]<|/det|>
A ball is at rest at the top of a hill. It rolls down the hill. At the bottom of the hill the ball hits a wall and stops.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 502, 370, 518]]<|/det|>
Which energy changes occur?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 530, 687, 548]]<|/det|>
A gravitational potential energy \(\rightarrow\) internal energy \(\rightarrow\) kinetic energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 687, 575]]<|/det|>
B gravitational potential energy \(\rightarrow\) kinetic energy \(\rightarrow\) internal energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 585, 687, 602]]<|/det|>
C kinetic energy \(\rightarrow\) gravitational potential energy \(\rightarrow\) internal energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 613, 687, 630]]<|/det|>
D kinetic energy \(\rightarrow\) internal energy \(\rightarrow\) gravitational potential energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 702, 91]]<|/det|>
A man pulls a truck a distance of \(20m\) , as shown in the three diagrams.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 101, 900, 384]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 392, 690, 410]]<|/det|>
Which statement concerning the work done against gravity is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 421, 344, 438]]<|/det|>
A Most work is done in 1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 327, 464]]<|/det|>
B No work is done in 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 443, 490]]<|/det|>
C The work done in all three is equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 499, 438, 515]]<|/det|>
D The work done in 1 and 2 is equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 543, 107, 561]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 843, 561]]<|/det|>
Which source of energy is used in a nuclear power station to generate electrical energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 572, 434, 588]]<|/det|>
A different types of atom regrouping

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 598, 327, 614]]<|/det|>
B heavy nuclei splitting

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 624, 400, 640]]<|/det|>
C radioactive isotopes decaying

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 460, 666]]<|/det|>
D radioactive atoms emitting \(\beta\) -particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 694, 107, 713]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 694, 722, 712]]<|/det|>
Two beakers are filled to the same depth, one with water and one with oil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 724, 695, 742]]<|/det|>
The density of water is \(1000kg / m^3\) and the density of oil is \(920kg / m^3\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 497, 772]]<|/det|>
In which position is the pressure the greatest?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 781, 750, 902]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 525, 90]]<|/det|> A water manometer is connected to a gas supply. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 100, 654, 260]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 271, 608, 288]]<|/det|> There is a gas leak and the pressure of the gas supply falls. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 301, 775, 318]]<|/det|> What happens to the water level at P and what happens to the water level at Q? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 330, 477, 459]]<|/det|>
water level at Pwater level at Q
Afallsfalls
Bfallsrises
Crisesfalls
Drisesrises

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|> A cylinder with a tap contains a fixed mass of gas X. The gas is contained by a piston which can move freely towards or away from the tap. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 114, 808, 221]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 233, 762, 250]]<|/det|> When the tap is opened, the piston moves slightly to the right, towards the tap. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 260, 799, 368]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 543, 396]]<|/det|> What can be deduced about the pressure of gas X? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 767, 536]]<|/det|>
before opening tapafter opening tap
Aless than atmospheric pressuremore than atmospheric pressure
Bsame as atmospheric pressuremore than atmospheric pressure
Cmore than atmospheric pressureless than atmospheric pressure
Dmore than atmospheric pressuresame as atmospheric pressure
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 107, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 737, 582]]<|/det|> Which quantity does **not** change when there is an increase in temperature? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 593, 374, 610]]<|/det|> A the density of a steel block <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 619, 468, 635]]<|/det|> B the diameter of the hole in a metal nut <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 645, 352, 661]]<|/det|> C the length of an iron rod <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 672, 357, 687]]<|/det|> D the mass of a metal coin <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 715, 107, 733]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 715, 470, 732]]<|/det|> A thermometer has a low thermal capacity. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 746, 337, 762]]<|/det|> Why is this an advantage? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 774, 853, 790]]<|/det|> A The thermometer does not absorb much thermal energy to raise its own temperature. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 790, 816]]<|/det|> B The thermometer does not conduct much thermal energy to the surroundings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 826, 552, 842]]<|/det|> C The thermometer does not melt when it gets hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 852, 782, 868]]<|/det|> D The thermometer does not radiate much thermal energy to the surroundings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 104]]<|/det|> In an experiment, a thermometer is placed in a test-tube of hot liquid. The temperature reading of the liquid is recorded every half minute. The table shows the results. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[70, 117, 936, 171]]<|/det|>
time/minutes0.00.51.01.52.02.53.03.54.04.55.05.56.06.57.07.5
temperature/°C73655955555551484542403836353433
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 475, 201]]<|/det|> What is the melting point of the substance? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 214, 700, 230]]<|/det|> A \(0^{\circ}\mathsf{C}\) B \(33^{\circ}\mathsf{C}\) C \(55^{\circ}\mathsf{C}\) D \(73^{\circ}\mathsf{C}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 260, 107, 276]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 259, 920, 306]]<|/det|> A teacher demonstrates an experiment to a class. A boiling tube is filled with water and some ice cubes are trapped at the bottom of the tube. The teacher then heats the boiling tube in the position shown until the water at the top boils. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 316, 600, 453]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 466, 301, 482]]<|/det|> The ice does not melt. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 497, 361, 513]]<|/det|> What does this demonstrate? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 526, 526, 542]]<|/det|> A Water is a good conductor of thermal energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 552, 526, 567]]<|/det|> B Water is a good convector of thermal energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 578, 522, 593]]<|/det|> C Water is a poor conductor of thermal energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 604, 522, 619]]<|/det|> D Water is a poor convector of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A hot metal plate is placed near to a cold metal plate. Infra-red radiation transfers thermal energy between the two plates. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 115, 713, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 285, 850, 303]]<|/det|> Which choice of colour causes the temperature of the cold plate to increase most slowly? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 316, 473, 443]]<|/det|>
hot platecold plate
Amatt blackmatt black
Bmatt blackshiny white
Cshiny whitematt black
Dshiny whiteshiny white
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 472, 107, 490]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 471, 871, 488]]<|/det|> Which row shows an example of a transverse wave and an example of a longitudinal wave? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 500, 430, 628]]<|/det|>
transverselongitudinal
Alightradio
Bradiosound
Csoundwater
Dwaterlight
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 657, 107, 675]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 657, 537, 674]]<|/det|> An object is placed before a plane mirror as shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 688, 655, 705]]<|/det|> A student views the image of the object in the mirror from point P. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 718, 387, 734]]<|/det|> Where does she see the image? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 744, 653, 899]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>23</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Light passes through a prism as shown. The light changes direction and produces a spectrum of colours.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[264, 117, 732, 235]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 248, 724, 265]]<|/det|>
Which term is used to describe the production of the spectrum of colours?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 277, 339, 370]]<|/det|>
A diffraction B dispersion C refraction D total internal reflection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 399, 107, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 399, 680, 415]]<|/det|>
Which type of waves are produced by a television remote controller?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 427, 285, 444]]<|/det|>
A infra-red waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 255, 470]]<|/det|>
B radio waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 480, 293, 495]]<|/det|>
C ultraviolet waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 248, 521]]<|/det|>
D visible light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 551, 107, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 551, 652, 567]]<|/det|>
Both the amplitude and the frequency of a sound wave decrease.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 410, 596]]<|/det|>
What happens to the sound heard?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 608, 510, 625]]<|/det|>
A The sound is louder and has a higher pitch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 635, 504, 651]]<|/det|>
B The sound is louder and has a lower pitch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 661, 514, 677]]<|/det|>
C The sound is quieter and has a higher pitch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 687, 506, 702]]<|/det|>
D The sound is quieter and has a lower pitch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 731, 107, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 731, 603, 747]]<|/det|>
An electromagnet is used to remove a splinter from an eye.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 761, 452, 777]]<|/det|>
What material is the splinter made from?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 789, 242, 804]]<|/det|>
A aluminium

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 816, 200, 831]]<|/det|>
B glass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 842, 185, 856]]<|/det|>
C iron

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 868, 200, 882]]<|/det|>
D wood

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 640, 90]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the magnetic field around a bar magnet?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 880, 432]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 458, 107, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 458, 482, 475]]<|/det|>
A metal conductor is connected to a battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 488, 635, 505]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the current in the metal conductor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 516, 133, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 516, 683, 534]]<|/det|>
It is a flow of electrons from the negative to the positive terminal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 543, 683, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 540, 683, 558]]<|/det|>
It is a flow of electrons from the positive to the negative terminal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 568, 668, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 568, 668, 585]]<|/det|>
It is a flow of protons from the negative to the positive terminal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 594, 668, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 594, 668, 612]]<|/det|>
It is a flow of protons from the positive to the negative terminal.

ammetersvoltmeters

ammeter readinglamp brightness

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 459, 107, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 920, 491]]<|/det|> Diagram 1 shows two identical lamps connected in series with a cell. Diagram 2 shows the same two lamps connected in parallel with an identical cell. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 501, 715, 654]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 350, 687]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 699, 892, 716]]<|/det|> A The cell in diagram 1 can supply current to the lamps for longer than the cell in diagram 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 725, 853, 742]]<|/det|> B The current in the cell in diagram 1 is greater than the current in the cell in diagram 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 752, 688, 768]]<|/det|> C The lamps in diagram 1 are brighter than the lamps in diagram 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 778, 840, 795]]<|/det|> D The voltage across each lamp in diagram 1 is greater than the voltage in diagram 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 456, 90]]<|/det|>
The diagram represents a magnetic field.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 100, 635, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 312, 313]]<|/det|>
What causes this field?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 325, 267, 342]]<|/det|>
**A** a bar magnet

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 390, 368]]<|/det|>
**B** a solenoid carrying a current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 420, 394]]<|/det|>
**C** a straight wire carrying a current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 400, 420]]<|/det|>
**D** two north poles close together

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 650, 465]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 666, 552, 683]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 694, 494, 711]]<|/det|>
**A** increasing the number of turns on the coil

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 721, 340, 737]]<|/det|>
**B** removing the magnets

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 747, 325, 763]]<|/det|>
**C** reversing the battery

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 773, 455, 789]]<|/det|>
**D** reversing the polarity of the magnets
